courses.name: Introduction to Women and Gender Studies

post.name: Honours Bachelor of Arts - Upper Year Transfer
Honours Bachelor of Science - Upper Year Transfer

subjectPost.name: Major - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies
Minor - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: This foundation course introduces the core ideas students will explore throughout their studies in Women and Gender Studies. It immerses students in a highly participatory and provocative encounter with history, social theory, politics, policy, art and culture seen through a gender lens. It provides an interdisciplinary overview of the historical 'waves' of women's movements for equality in a global context and background to the development of Women/Gender Studies as a site of learning and feminist inquiry.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Women and Gender Studies
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Reading and Writing in Women and Gender Studies

post.name: Honours Bachelor of Arts - Upper Year Transfer
Honours Bachelor of Science - Upper Year Transfer

cmCourseInfo.description: Using key feminist texts, this course advances students thinking, reading and writing in the discipline of Women and Gender Studies. The emphasis is placed on the development and application of interdisciplinary skills in the interpretation, analysis, criticism, and advocacy of ideas encountered in Women and Gender Studies. [24L, 12T]
cmCourseInfo.title: Reading and Writing in Women and Gender Studies
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Introduction to Women and Gender Studies

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: An integrated and historical approach to social relations of gender, race, class, sexuality and disability, particularly as they relate to women's lives and struggles across different locales, including Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Women and Gender Studies

courses.name: Theories in Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an opportunity to engage in an in-depth examination of specialized and scholarly work within women, gender, and sexuality studies with a focus on the diverse and multidisciplinary expressions of feminist thought from the perspective of postcolonial, transnational, intersectional, diasporic, Black feminist, indigenous, and queer theories. This course situates the importance of praxis, the relationship between theory and social practice, to women, gender, and sexuality studies. Students will engage throughout with the relationship between theories of gender and sexuality as they relate to, and are inseparable from, an understanding of race and racial formations. It incorporates study of the themes and debates concerning the socially constructed categories of gender and sexuality in historical and contemporary contexts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theories in Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS101H5
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Fundamentals of Research in Women and Gender Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: This interdisciplinary course focuses on the visions and methods that feminist scholars use to study women's and gender issues within and across a range of traditional disciplines. The course explores feminist epistemologies and research methods to understand how to carry out feminist research. We will focus on how feminist scholars challenge dominant theories of knowledge and the major methodologies employed in the social sciences and humanities. [24L]
cmCourseInfo.title: Fundamentals of Research in Women and Gender Studies
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Introduction to Feminism and Popular Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the forms and functions of popular culture and its representation and understanding of the social category of women. It examines specific media forms including, but not limited to, film, song, visual arts, music, video, television, advertising and new media forms. It critically analyzes the impact of these portrayals on women in society while examining the cultural constructions of race, sexuality, class and ability. [24L, 12T]
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Feminism and Popular Culture
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS271Y1 or WSTB13H3. May not be taken with or after WGS470H5.
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Women in Families

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies how the notion of family is conceptualized and organized transnationally and historically and examines the multiple familiar roles of women in diverse contexts. [24L, 12T]
cmCourseInfo.title: Women in Families
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Texts, Theories, Histories

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines modes of theories that shaped feminist thought and situates them historically and transnationally so as to emphasize the social conditions and conflicts in which ideas and politics arise, change and circulate.
cmCourseInfo.title: Texts, Theories, Histories

courses.name: Texts, Theories, Histories

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines modes of theories that shaped feminist thought and situates them historically and transnationally so as to emphasize the social conditions and conflicts in which ideas and politics arise, change and circulate.
cmCourseInfo.title: Texts, Theories, Histories

courses.name: Gender in Popular Culture

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical examination of institutions, representations and practices associated with contemporary popular culture, mass-produced, local and alternative.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender in Popular Culture

courses.name: Gender & Environmental (In)Justice

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Using a transnational, feminist framework, this course examines material and conceptual interrelations between gendered human and non-human nature, ecological crises, political economies and environmental movements in a variety of geographical, historical and cultural contexts. Does environmental justice include social justice, or are they in conflict? What might environmental justice and activism involve?
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender & Environmental (In)Justice

courses.name: Men and Masculinities

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines how masculinities shape the lives of men, women, transgender people. Effects of construction, reproduction and impact of masculinities on institutions such as education, work, religion, sports, family, medicine, military and the media are explored. Provides critical analysis of how masculinities shape individual lives, groups, organizations and social movements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Men and Masculinities

courses.name: Women, Migration and Diaspora

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the process of migration to Canada from a gender perspective, noting the interplay between structural impediments and women's own agency. Historical perspectives on migration and government policy, and on ways women have rebuilt lives and shaped communities.
cmCourseInfo.title: Women, Migration and Diaspora
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ERI335H5 or NEW335H1 or WGS380H1 or WSTB06H3
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Bodies That Matter: Disability Sexual Subjectivity and the the Politics of Desire

cmCourseInfo.description: A special topic by guest instructor. Topics vary from year to year. Visit the Departmental web site at Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies for further information.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Women and Gender Studies
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Women and Revolution in the Middle East

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the complex and conflictual relations between women and revolutionary struggles and focuses on a number of theoretical and empirical issues relevant to the Middle East and North Africa context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Women and Revolution in the Middle East
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS335H1 Women and Revolution in the Middle East

courses.name: Black Feminisms: Diasporic Conversations on Theory and Practice

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines how Black Feminisms are theorized, produced and practiced, by predominantly Black women scholars, activists and cultural producers located in the diaspora - Canada, the United States and the Caribbean.
cmCourseInfo.title: Black Feminisms: Diasporic Conversations on Theory and Practice
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS101H5 or WGS200Y5
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Critical Race Theory in Women and Gender Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: This course's central focus is an examination of the way race and gender operate together in structuring social inequality. It offers the analytical tools for exploring the interconnections between race and gender, along with other systems of domination, and incorporates perspectives from women of colour and from women in the global "South."
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Race Theory in Women and Gender Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS200Y5
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Gender, Race, and Surveillance

cmCourseInfo.description: From forced sterilization and sex-selective abortion, to selfies, prisons, and biosecurity, this course conceptualizes suspicion and technologies of surveillance in transnational perspectives. Informed by a range of interdisciplinary scholarship, namely critical transnational feminist and Black feminist texts, it interrogates how surveillance has long enacted racialized, gendered, and biopolitical injustices.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender, Race, and Surveillance
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS200Y5
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Theories of Masculinity

cmCourseInfo.description: Working with gender studies' theories, this course draws on social and cultural constructions and practices to offer a complex reading of masculinities. It explores contemporary debates of the ways in which masculinities have been theorized and experienced in practices and identity formation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theories of Masculinity
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Gendered Labour Around the World

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will focus on masculinities and femininities in workplace settings, with an emphasis on service work around the world. We will discuss workers' lived experiences of gender regimes which are embedded within the dynamics of class, race and nation. The relationships between gender processes and workplace hierarchies will be explored.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gendered Labour Around the World
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS363H1 Gendered Labour Around the World

courses.name: Wired Women: Gender, Cyberspace and New Information Technology

cmCourseInfo.description: The course examines how computer technologies facilitate women's participation in cyberspace and how women define and construct their involvement. It studies the simultaneous generation of new modalities of empowerment and disempowerment including language, role-playing, communication, gaming, and networking and conduits for sex trafficking, harassment and other forums of exploitation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Wired Women: Gender, Cyberspace and New Information Technology
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Making Knowledge in a World that Matters

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Teaches skills in feminist approaches to making knowledge. Introduces feminist practices for doing research and navigating the politics of production and exchange. Develops skills for conveying knowledge to the wider world, such as through research papers, reports, performance, new media, art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Making Knowledge in a World that Matters
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS160Y1

courses.name: Gender Issues in the Law

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the operation of the law as it affects women, the construction and representation of women within the legal system, and the scope for feminist and intersectional analyses of law. Includes an analysis of specific legal issues such as sexuality and reproduction, equality, employment, violence and immigration.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender Issues in the Law

courses.name: Women and Psychology

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary analysis of the relationship of women to a variety of psychological and psychoanalytical theories and practices. Topics include gender development, stereotyping and gender roles, the impact of gender on intimate relationships, women and the psychological establishment, women's mental health issues and feminist approaches to psychoanalysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Women and Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS200Y5
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: The Politics of Gender and Health

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines diverse traditions and normative models of health (e.g. biomedicine, social constructionist, indigenous health) in conjunction with analyses of the origin, politics, and theoretical perspectives of contemporary Women's Health Movements. Topics may include fertility, sexuality, poverty, violence, labour, aging, (dis)ability, and health care provision.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Politics of Gender and Health

courses.name: Women and Health

cmCourseInfo.description: Feminist theories and frameworks examining the interconnections between women, health and biomedicine in North America and transnationally.
cmCourseInfo.title: Women and Health
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Women in World Cultures

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the diversity and shared experiences of women in western and non-western societies. This is primarily a history course, supplemented with some contemporary perspectives. It compares women in diverse economic, cultural and religious settings. As part of this course, students may have the option of participating in an international learning experience that will have an additional cost and application process.
cmCourseInfo.title: Women in World Cultures
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Studies in Post-Colonialism

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines gendered representations of race, ethnicity, class, sexuality and disability in a variety of colonial, neo-colonial, and post-colonial contexts. Topics may include the emergence of racialist, feminist, liberatory and neoconservative discourses as inscribed in literary texts, historical documents, cultural artifacts and mass media.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Post-Colonialism

courses.name: Utopian Visions, Activist Realities

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Drawing on diversely situated case-studies, this course focuses on the ideals that inform struggles for social justice, and the mechanisms activists have employed to produce the change. Foci include the gendered implications of movement participation, local and transnational coalition, alternative community formation, and encounters with the state and inter/supra/transnational organizations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Utopian Visions, Activist Realities

courses.name: Theories of Sexuality

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a critical overview of contemporary theories of sexuality, focusing on transnational discussions by feminists and queer theorists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theories of Sexuality
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Gender and Violence

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary study of gendered violence in both historical and contemporary contexts including topics such as textual and visual representations; legal and theoretical analyses; structural violence; war and militarization; sexual violence; and resistance and community mobilization.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender and Violence

courses.name: Gender, Violence and Resistance

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will focus on how gender and violence shapes and impacts the lives of women and LGBT persons. The course will explore the concept of gender and the myriad of ways in which it has been shaped by historical, and contextual relations of power and privilege. The course will explore how scholars in the feminist/women's movement have defined the concept of violence as it impacts women and girls.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender, Violence and Resistance
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Feminist Studies in Sexuality

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Sexual agency as understood and enacted by women in diverse cultural and historical contexts. An exploration of the ways in which women have theorized and experienced sexual expectations, practices and identities. This course will be offered every three years.
cmCourseInfo.title: Feminist Studies in Sexuality

courses.name: Studies in Queer and Trans

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Takes up conversations in queer and trans studies as separate and entangled fields. It explores how queer and trans people have experienced and theorized gender and sexuality.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Queer and Trans

courses.name: Feminist Graphic Novels

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Comics aren't new, and graphic novels aren't either, but feminists have built a rich array of stories about consciousness, resistance, and coming of age in this genre that warrant scholarly attention. In this case, we will read graphic novels for their subtleties, thinking about what picture and text make possible in the exploration of emotion, interconnection, and identity. Reading about resistance to marriage in Aya of Yop City, a child's view of revolution in Persepolis, parent child reckoning in Fun Home, and loneliness in Skim will advance students' understandings of the of the power of narrative and the pictorial displacement of innocence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Feminist Graphic Novels
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS160Y1Y or WGS271Y1Y or 1.0 WGS credit

courses.name: Gender and Neoliberalism

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Reviews major feminist transnational, Marxist and Foucauldian approaches to the study of neoliberalism. Adopts a comparative, historical and global approach to the ways that gender is implicated in state restructuring, changing roles for corporations and non-governmental organizations, changing norms for personhood, sovereignty and citizenship, and changing ideas about time/space.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender and Neoliberalism

courses.name: Land-ing: Indigenous and Black Futurist Spaces

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Students are invited to think through the relationships between Indigenous and Afro-futurist concepts of land. This class will engage Indigenous feminist and Black queer and feminist theories of land and space, linking them to Afrofuturist and Indigenous futurist thought. We explore various texts in relation to emergent methodologies, decolonial desires, and love and radical relationalities.
cmCourseInfo.title: Land-ing: Indigenous and Black Futurist Spaces
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 4.0 credits
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS335H1 (Special Topic in Women and Gender Studies: Indigenous Feminist Theory), offered in Fall 2015, WGS335H1 (Special Topic in Women and Gender Studies: Decolonial Aesthetics and Futurities), offered in Winter 2018, Winter 2019 and Winter 2020

courses.name: Writing the Body

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the ways in which bodies are lived and inscribed and represented through a variety of genres. Students will work through issues of corporeality and materiality in the production and reception of texts and will practice embodied writing on a personal level through in-class workshops and written assignments.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing the Body

courses.name: Independent Project in Study of Women & Gender

subjectPost.name: Major - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies
Minor - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity to carry out an extended research project under the supervision of a faculty member. A proposal must be presented to the faculty member and consent obtained before the end of the July registration period.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Project in Study of Women & Gender
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS200Y5 and 2.0 WGS 300+ level credits
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

courses.name: Gender and Globalization: Transnational Perspectives

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Critically examines current interdisciplinary scholarship on globalization, its intersections with gender, power structures, and feminized economies. Related socio-spatial reconfigurations, ‘glocal’ convergences, and tensions are explored, with emphasis on feminist counter-narratives and theorizing of globalization, theoretical debates on the meanings and impacts of globalization, and possibilities of resistance, agency, and change.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender and Globalization: Transnational Perspectives
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.5 WGS credits including WGS160Y1 and 1.0 WGS credit at the 300+ level
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS463H1 (Advanced Topics in Gender Theory: Gender and Globalization: Transnational Perspectives), offered in Fall 2009

courses.name: Diasporic Sexualities

cmCourseInfo.description: What can diaspora studies teach us about sexuality studies? And, what can sexuality studies teach us about diaspora studies? This class examines the relationship between diaspora studies, sexuality studies, and feminist studies by focusing on how diasporic movements of bodies have altered and transformed modern conceptualizations of gender and sexuality. It will investigate how diasporic subjects negotiate their relationship to constructs of home and (un)belonging.
cmCourseInfo.title: Diasporic Sexualities
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS200Y5 and 1.0 WGS300+ level credits
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: WGS202H5 or WGS205H5 or DTS201H5 or DTS202H5 or DTS301H5 or DTS401H5
publicationSections: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

cmPublicationSections.section: UTM - Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Feminist Listening: Critical and Intersectional Approaches to Popular Music

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program

courses.name: Toxic Worlds, Decolonial Futures

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the ways environmental violence is an integral practice of settler colonialism that affects human and non-human life, disrupts Indigenous sovereignty, and enacts ongoing racism. A typical way of addressing environmental violence is to document the harm done to bodies and communities. This class asks, how might we also refuse environmental violence and enact better obligations to land/body relations? What kind of decolonial futures can be summoned in the aftermath of environmental violence? Our readings will bring Indigenous feminist approaches together with Black feminist, queer, and feminist environmental justice approaches. Participants will build upon the readings to create their own decolonial environmental justice future projects.
cmCourseInfo.title: Toxic Worlds, Decolonial Futures
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.5 WGS credits including WGS160Y1 and 1.0 WGS credit at the 300+ level
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS463H1 (Advanced Topics in Gender Theory: Toxic Worlds, Decolonial Futures), offered in Winter 2018, Winter 2019 and Winter 2020

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is restricted to two groups of students. Group 1 is given priority access until July 23. Beginning July 25, Group 2 can enrol in this course.
Group 1: Year 3 students in ASMAJ0571-MA WOMEN AND GENDER STUDIES
Group 1: Year 3 students in ASSPE0571-SP WOMEN AND GENDER STUDIES
Group 1: Year 4 students in ASMAJ0571-MA WOMEN AND GENDER STUDIES
Group 1: Year 4 students in ASSPE0571-SP WOMEN AND GENDER STUDIES
Group 2: Year 3 students in ASMIN0571-MI WOMEN AND GENDER STUDIES
Group 2: Year 4 students in ASMIN0571-MI WOMEN AND GENDER STUDIES

courses.name: Independent Study in Women and Gender Studies Issues

cmCourseInfo.description: Under supervision, students pursue topics in Women and Gender Studies not currently part of the curriculum. For students in the Women and Gender Studies Specialist or Major. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Study in Women and Gender Studies Issues
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of WGS160Y1, WGS260H1, and WGS360H1, a CGPA of at least 3.0 and permission of the Undergraduate Coordinator.

cmCourseInfo.description: Supervised undergraduate thesis project undertaken in the final year of study. Students attend a bi-weekly seminar to discuss research strategies, analytics, methods and findings. A required course for Specialist students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.description: The application of theoretical study to practical community experience. Advanced Women and Gender Studies students have the opportunity to apply knowledge acquired in the Women and Gender Studies curriculum through a practicum placement within a community organization. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.5 WGS credits including WGS160Y1 and 1.0 WGS credit at the 300+ level

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality and Black Liberation from Black Power to #BlackLivesMatter

subjectPost.name: Women and Gender Studies Major Program
Women and Gender Studies Minor Program
Women and Gender Studies Specialist Program

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course maps genealogies of black insurgency and transnational itineraries of intersectional theorizing, organizing, and praxis from the 20th century to our present moment. Through close study of works by and about black revolutionary migrants, exiles, intellectuals, fugitives, and so-called terrorists, participants will critique and create radical visions for emancipation. Major topics and themes may include black feminisms; queer insurgencies; transnational imaginaries and solidarities; silence and intracommunal violence; accountability and transformative justice. Through collective discussion, writing, and reflection we interrogate visions and strategies of emancipation, and imagine radical futures historically and in our own times.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender, Sexuality and Black Liberation from Black Power to #BlackLivesMatter
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.5 WGS credits including WGS160Y1 and 1.0 WGS credit at the 300+ level
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS435H1 (Topics: Sex, Gender and Revolution from Black Power to #BlackLivesMatter), offered in Winter 2017 and Fall 2017
